title: How To Train Your Dog To Wait
summary: The first step in getting your dog to wait is to get him to stop following you when you leave the room. It’s important that you don’t physically keep your dog in one place by holding his collar, wrapping a leash around his chest, or using any kind of physical restraint. This can create an association in the dog's mind that you doing this means he should stay put. You can use shaping techniques to help your dog learn to wait for longer periods of time.

var g=Object.defineProperty,l=Object.defineProperties;var p=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors;var a=Object.getOwnPropertySymbols;var h=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty,r=Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable;var s=(t,o,e)=>o in t?g(t,o,{enumerable:!0,configurable:!0,writable:!0,value:e}):t[o]=e,n=(t,o)=>{for(var e in o||(o={}))h.call(o,e)&&s(t,e,o[e]);if(a)for(var e of a(o))r.call(o,e)&&s(t,e,o[e]);return t},d=(t,o)=>l(t,p(o));var u=(t,o)=>{var e={};for(var i in t)h.call(t,i)&&o.indexOf(i)<0&&(e[i]=t[i]);if(t!=null&&a)for(var i of a(t))o.indexOf(i)<0&&r.call(t,i)&&(e[i]=t[i]);return e};const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent(e){var i=e,{components:t}=i,o=u(i,["components"]);return mdx(MDXLayout,d(n(n({},layoutProps),o),{components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"}),mdx("h2",null,"The Basics of Teaching a Dog to Wait"),mdx("p",null,"The first step in teaching your dog to wait is to get him to understand the word \u201CWait\u201D. This could be a word you use exclusively for this purpose, or it could be one of the many \u201CC\u201D and \u201CK\u201D words that dogs already understand and we use all the time. Whichever word you choose, you should be consistent about using it for this purpose only."),mdx("p",null,"While you\u2019re working on this training, it\u2019s important that you don\u2019t physically keep your dog in one place by holding his collar, wrapping a leash around his chest, or using any kind of physical restraint. This can create an association in the dog\u2019s mind that you doing this means he should stay put. But if you want to keep him in one place while you\u2019re not there, you\u2019ll need to use a different method that doesn\u2019t give him negative associations with your presence."),mdx("h2",null,"Establishing a \u201CWait\u201D Command"),mdx("p",null,`The first step in getting your dog to wait is to get him to stop following you when you leave the room. The way to do this is to say the word \u201CWait\u201D, and then leave the room.
Once he\u2019s by himself in the room, he will probably start wondering what he\u2019s supposed to do now. It\u2019s at this point that he might start scratching at the door or jumping at it in an attempt to follow you. If he does, praise him and tell him \u201CWait\u201D again, but don\u2019t let him out of the room.
Wait until he\u2019s stopped scratching or pawing at the door, and then go back into the room and praise him again.`),mdx("h2",null,"Reinforcing Behaviors You Like"),mdx("p",null,`Once you\u2019ve gotten your dog to understand the word \u201CWait\u201D and you\u2019ve begun to train him to stay in the room, you can start rewarding him for staying put. Rewarding him can take a number of different forms, but it\u2019s important that you only reward him while he\u2019s waiting, not while he\u2019s scratching at the door.
Wait until he\u2019s relaxed and stopped pawing at the door, and then praise him and give him a small treat.
This can be a great way to reinforce the \u201CWait\u201D command, and it can help him associate the command with something positive.`),mdx("h2",null,"Shaping Behaviors You Want"),mdx("p",null,`As you progress with your training, you can use shaping techniques to help your dog learn to wait for longer periods of time. This process will help him associate waiting with the door or barrier you want him to stay behind and not with you or your actions.
Wait until he\u2019s relaxed and stopped pawing or scratching at the door, and then stand next to the barrier with the treat in your hand and wait again.
When he turns away from the door, even if he\u2019s still waiting and looking in that direction, praise him and give him the treat.
Wait until he turns away from the barrier again, and then repeat.
Once he\u2019s good at this, you can start introducing other distractions that are happening in the room with him.`),mdx("h2",null,"How to Build on What You\u2019ve Taught So Far"),mdx("p",null,`Once you\u2019ve gotten your dog to understand that he should stay in the room and not follow you when you leave, you can start adding new behaviors to the process while keeping the other ones consistent.
Once he\u2019s waiting by the door or barrier, you can walk away from him and give him the \u201CWait\u201D command.
When he turns away from the door and starts to follow you, tell him \u201CWait\u201D again with a slight pause between the two words.
Wait until he turns away from the door again and then praise him and let him follow you.
Continue this process until he\u2019s good at following you while remaining in the room.`),mdx("h2",null,"Wrapping Up"),mdx("p",null,"As you continue working with your dog, you can start to add more distractions to the process, such as having people in the room or having other dogs with him. You can also start experimenting with new environments and see how your dog does waiting in other places."),mdx("p",null,"The important thing to remember is that you must be consistent with your training and you must reward your dog for doing what you want him to do. If you don\u2019t, you\u2019ll find that you\u2019ll get nowhere with your training, and your dog may even stop following the \u201CWait\u201D command you\u2019ve already taught him."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

The mediator doesn\u2019t take sides, but instead helps both parties understand each other\u2019s point of view. This way, the disputants can agree on a fair outcome and put an end to their disagreements.
If you are part of an organization that is going through a lot of conflict right now (or any time soon), mediation might be a good solution for reducing tensions, smoothing things over and getting everyone back on track. Here we\u2019ll explain what mediation is, why it works so well for resolving conflicts and how you can initiate it in your organization.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

How to Train Your Dog to Allow You to Groom Them

While this is true in a lot of cases, it\u2019t necessarily the case all the time. Depending on your dog\u2019s breed and their natural instincts, you might find that grooming them can prove to be a very tricky task. If you have struggled to get your dog used to being groomed for some time now, there are several tips and tricks you can use to help train them to allow you to do so.
Dog grooming is something that many pet owners struggle with from time to time, especially if your pet has a specific type of fur that doesn\u2019t grow too much like long hair or curly hair. It\u2019s natural for dogs to dislike having their hair caught in things like bushes or trees while they hunt or run around outside; however, it can also be difficult when trying to keep their hair short and tidy at home.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

It is a process that brings people together to resolve conflict and find mutually satisfying solutions. In mediation, an impartial third party assists the disputing parties in identifying the issues, exploring their own role in it and accessing their core needs to come up with a solution that works for all parties involved.
Mediation is a confidential process and there are many types of mediation depending on the nature of conflict. For example, dispute resolution could be focusing on specific issues such as environmental concerns or human resources issues; it could be between two parties such as divorce mediation or landlord-tenant mediation; it could be on a particular topic like civil rights mediation or criminal mediation; or it could be based on certain factors like age, gender, sexual orientation or physical ability. The following article explores the ways in which mediation can help you.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

How to Train Your Dog Not to Chew on Household Items

intro.compiledSource:
var y=Object.defineProperty,d=Object.defineProperties;var c=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors;var a=Object.getOwnPropertySymbols;var s=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty,i=Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable;var r=(o,t,e)=>t in o?y(o,t,{enumerable:!0,configurable:!0,writable:!0,value:e}):o[t]=e,h=(o,t)=>{for(var e in t||(t={}))s.call(t,e)&&r(o,e,t[e]);if(a)for(var e of a(t))i.call(t,e)&&r(o,e,t[e]);return o},u=(o,t)=>d(o,c(t));var l=(o,t)=>{var e={};for(var n in o)s.call(o,n)&&t.indexOf(n)<0&&(e[n]=o[n]);if(o!=null&&a)for(var n of a(o))t.indexOf(n)<0&&i.call(o,n)&&(e[n]=o[n]);return e};const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent(e){var n=e,{components:o}=n,t=l(n,["components"]);return mdx(MDXLayout,u(h(h({},layoutProps),t),{components:o,mdxType:"MDXLayout"}),mdx("p",null,`Are you ready to give up chewing on household objects? How about your dog? Dogs love to chew. It\u2019s something that comes naturally for them, and there are many things you can buy or make that will help satisfy their natural instincts to chew. But as much as dogs love to have objects that they can gnaw on, it\u2019s not always safe \u2013 or advisable \u2013 to let them do it in the home. There are plenty of household items that dogs shouldn\u2019t be allowed to chew, because it could lead to potential hazards or unsanitary conditions.
Even if your dog has never chewed on inappropriate things before, a new puppy will almost certainly try out things beyond what is safe for him. How you train him from the very beginning will determine how much damage he can do if he goes after something he shouldn\u2019t. So read on and learn how to stop your dog from chewing on anything other than his own toys.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

It\u2019t also a kind and selfless act, as you are giving another creature a second chance at life. However, adopting a pet can be quite the ordeal. You must first understand the ins and outs of owning pets, choose whether you want to adopt an adult or juvenile animal, narrow down your selection of potential pets by checking their housing requirements, veterinarian references and character traits, and finally interview prospective pets before bringing them home with you.
There are many different types of animals that you can adopt as a pet. Read on to find out more about adopting an Australian labradoodle as your new pet!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
